llm_processed_output.source_summary: This paper analyzes the political role of the Banu Qasi, a Muladi family in the Upper March of Al-Andalus, from their conversion to Islam in 714 to their decline in 924. It examines their interactions with the Umayyad Emirate/Caliphate of Cordoba, the Christian kingdoms to the north, and other local powers. The study covers the family's rise to prominence, particularly under Musa ibn Musa, who became a powerful figure in the region, and their subsequent decline due to internal divisions and external pressures. The paper details their political strategies, alliances, and conflicts, highlighting their significance in the context of the political landscape of Al-Andalus and the formation of the Kingdom of Pamplona. It also touches on the historiography of the Banu Qasi and the challenges of studying the Muladi population in Al-Andalus. The decline of the Banu Qasi at the end of the period was directly linked to conflicts and power shifts culminating in their removal from the Upper March by Abd-al-Rahman III.
extracted_key_facts: The Banu Qasi were a significant Muladi family in the Upper March of Al-Andalus, active from 714 to 924.
The family's ancestor, Count Cassius, converted to Islam in 714 and allied with Musa ibn Nusayr.
The Banu Qasi initially represented Cordoba's interests in the Ebro Valley, similar to their previous role with Toledo.
Musa ibn Musa (died 862) was a prominent member of the Banu Qasi, considered a powerful leader in the region, and was even referred to as the 'third king of Spain' by some Christian chroniclers.
Musa ibn Musa held positions such as governor of Tudela (850) and wali of Zaragoza (852), giving him control over the Upper March.
The Banu Qasi family's political strategy involved maintaining a balance between loyalty to Cordoba, alliances with Christian rulers, and the protection of their own interests.
Internal divisions and conflicts with the Umayyad rulers of Cordoba contributed to the Banu Qasi's decline after the death of Musa ibn Musa.
Muhammad I of Cordoba ordered the reconstruction of Calatayud in 872 as a stronghold against the Banu Qasi and elevated the sons of 'Abd al-'Aziz al-Tushubi.
The Banu Qasi lost control of Zaragoza in 884.
Lope ibn Muhammad, grandson of Musa, sealed peace with Cordoba, causing a family fracture.
Sancho Garces of Pamplona defeated and killed Muhammad ibn Lope in 907.
Abd al-Rahman III removed the Banu Qasi from the Upper March in 924 and relocated them to Cordoba, replacing them with the Tujibids.
The decline of the Banu Qasi was influenced by the rise of the Kingdom of Pamplona and its alliance with the Kingdom of Leon.
The term 'musālima' designated converts to Islam, while 'muwallad' referred to Christians who had become Arabized, and 'asālima' defined Christians converting to Islam.
The family's origin traces back to a comes or iudex of the Visigothic era who embraced Islam upon the arrival of Muslim forces in the Iberian Peninsula.
The initial adhesion of the Muladi element was likely larger than that of Mozarabs, with the Muladis being associated with agriculture, livestock, fishing, and crafts.
